messageBody:
On 2/22/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> > A more common way to address this problem is to catch the exception and
> do a
> > fail().
>
> I don't quite understand this. If the test expects the exception, then
> we usually catch it and /don't/ fail; but if the test doesn't expect the
> exception, then we usually throw it up into JUnit and let it report the
> error.


Sorry, I meant to put the fail in the try{} block of course, not catch{}.

The point was that letting the method throw and declare the exception in the
throws clause is not considered the best way to test for exceptions.

Of course, all of this is moot with JUnit4 / TestNG :-)
